After leaving the Mesa Verde area, the rock formations continue stretching off into the distance.
More mesas pop up in the desert as you drive southwest, with more and more stark character.
Rocks jutting straight into the sky.
The rocks are turning more red, and seem more arid.
Long, straight desert roads.

Looking out around the sides of the mesa.

A long abandoned building.
Jagged rocks reaching for the sky.
Getting closer to the painted desert, the rocks and sand take on more and more red hues.
A tall tower out in the middle of nowhere. Never seen another one like it, with the pipeline coming out and down. Oil?
Sunset approaches in the painted desert.

The arid desert is transformed into a seemingly tropical paradise.
Panoramic shot coming down to the bridge crossing over the Colorado.
Some of the last stairs for the day!
The suspension bridge that spans the river is impressive; it can support a party of at least 10 donkeys with riders and gear.
Bridge crossing selfie!
The beach on the other side.
Just beauty.

From the other side now.
Entrance to the beach.
A cabin at Phantom Ranch.
More ranch cabins.
The cantina at Phantom Ranch. They served Thanksgiving dinner here tonight, which we tried to get in on, but people plan their entire year around it. We had mac n cheese and ramen instead. Just like the Pilgrims did.
The ranger station at Bright Angel campground.
The view walking towards the campground from the ranch.
A power and telephone line pole, with old glass insulators.
Sunrise accenting the cascading walls up ahead.
A moss covered springfall down a rock wall.
The hike up the Bright Angel trail provided a day-long sunrise, hence the name. The sun is peaking behind some rocks again here.
A huge wall full of blocky ledges.
A stream cutting down along the trail.
